content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

In Julia, you can use the `Dates` package to manipulate date-time objects. Here is how you can create this function:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df[:dt])
    return df
end
```
This function takes a `DataFrame` as input and adds a new column "ym" to it which is the concatenation of year and month from each DateTime in "dt". The `map` function applies a function (in this case, extracting the year and month) to every element in the "dt" column.

Note: This assumes that your DataFrame has a column named "dt" representing DateTimes. If not, you will need to adjust the function accordingly.
